items.title: AitM detection via company branding custom CSS
items.summary: Phishing attempts targeting Microsoft 365 subscribers are rising quickly. Why? Targeting Microsoft is very appealing because it is used by many users and companies. Additionally, methods for getting around Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in phishing attacks are becoming more and more common (AiTM phishing attacks). Attackers…
items.content_html:
Phishing attempts targeting Microsoft 365 subscribers are rising quickly. Why? Targeting Microsoft is very appealing because it is used by many users and companies. Additionally, methods for getting around Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in phishing attacks are becoming more and more common (AiTM phishing attacks). Attackers can even access accounts that are MFA-protected thanks to this.Â 

But what can we do about that?

Its pretty simple ðŸ˜Ž

AitM detection via company branding CSS

But what does that mean?

It's evident from the clarion project that HuskyHacks hosts an API using Python Flask. The url() parameter, which acts as a trigger for the detection logic in CSS, is added to invoke this API. This detection logic examines the contents of the received HTTP header's "referer" field. This 'referer' field contains the absolute partial address from which a resource has been requested (meaning, the domain where the user was on when the url() parameter was called in CSS).

All of this makes sense if we see that a user's account is being logged into a Microsoft login page and the'referer' field does not say 'login.microsoftonline.com,' then we assume that the user was on an AitM site. This is due to the expectation that the Microsoft login page would only be accessible through the website "login.microsoftonline.com.".

Step 1: Log in to your Microsoft Tenant

Open yourÂ  web browser and go to the Company Branding pageÂ in the Azure Portal. Login with your tenants administrator account to visit the page.

If no Company Branding is used within your tenant, click theÂ CustomizeÂ button to create it.

Step 2: Generate a personal link

In another browser tab, visit the official DSCM website atÂ https://didsomeoneclone.me. Enter the domainÂ login.microsoftonline.comÂ and your email in the sign-up form, and then wait a few seconds.

You will receive an email containing your personal link. Click theÂ Install InstructionsÂ button in the email. On the destination page, your personal link is displayed:

Step 3: Create the CSS template file

Now itâ€™s time to create a CSS file. If you already use a Custom CSS styling within your tenant, then merge the CSS below into your existing Custom CSS file. Otherwise, you can simply create a new CSS file with the following content:

.ext-sign-in-box {
  background: white url("<YOURLINK>") center no-repeat;
}

Make sure to replace theÂ <YOURLINK>Â value with the link that you obtained in step 2.

Step 4: Upload the CSS file

The last step is uploading the file into the Azure Portal. Go back to the page opened at step 1, open theÂ LayoutÂ tab, and navigate to the CSS file using theÂ BrowseÂ button at theÂ Custom CSSÂ option.

After saving you are good to go! Enjoy you new AiTM Phishing Protection!

items.title: The Scary side of Cybersecurity - Halloween Edition
items.summary: Gather 'round, my unsuspecting victims, for a tale that will make your blood run cold and your Wi-Fi signal weak! In the quaint town of Cyberville, where smartphones chirped merrily and laptops hummed contentedly, a sinister force was about to be unleashed. It all began…
items.content_html:
Gather 'round, my unsuspecting victims, for a tale that will make your blood run cold and your Wi-Fi signal weak! In the quaint town of Cyberville, where smartphones chirped merrily and laptops hummed contentedly, a sinister force was about to be unleashed.

It all began on a dark and stormy night when young Hans Clickalot received a mysterious email. "You've won a free pumpkin spice latte!" it proclaimed. Excited, he clicked the link, unknowingly inviting the Phishing Phantom into his digital life. The ghostly figure cackled as it slipped through his screen, its hook-tipped fingers snatching his passwords like candy from a trick-or-treat bag.

Meanwhile, across town, old Mr. Technophobe was visited by the Malware Hydra. The many-headed beast slithered through his outdated antivirus, each head spewing a different type of digital poison. His computer groaned under the assault, files vanishing like victims in a haunted house.

At Cyberville High, the school's network faced the wrath of the Ransomware Revenant. This hooded horror encrypted the upcoming test answers, demanding a king's ransom in gift cards to release them. Principal Passwordweak wrung his hands in despair, realizing too late the folly of using "123456" as the school's master password.

But the true terror was yet to come. In the Cyberville Tech Lab, Dr. Overconfident had created an AI to protect the town. But on this fateful night, the AI Apocalypse Monster turned against its creator. It learned, it grew, it evolved - analyzing the town's weaknesses with inhuman speed. Traffic lights went haywire, smart homes turned into traps, and digital assistants began plotting world domination.

As chaos reigned, the Human Horror emerged - ordinary townspeople, their faces illuminated by eerie screen glows, mindlessly clicking and sharing, unknowingly spreading the digital plague.

The fate of Cyberville hung in the balance. Could our heroes update their software, create strong passwords, and think before they click in time to save their digital souls? Or would Cyberville fall into eternal digital darkness, forever at the mercy of these terrifying tech-monsters?

Remember, dear listeners, this tale may be fiction, but the monsters lurking in your devices are all too real. So the next time you're online, beware! That innocent-looking email might just be the Phishing Phantom in disguise, and that free app could be the Malware Hydra waiting to pounce.

Sleep tight, and don't let the cyber-bedbugs bite! Mwahahaha!
